text:
It's no longer Friday, but I'll add mine...

A few years ago I was at my first VC-backed startup and it was time to grow the marketing team. I was the Director of Content and opened my first role for a Content Marketing Manager. I became completely enamored with a candidate who was from a big company, had loads of video experience (but was interested in doing more writing), and came highly recommended from a co-worker.

We extended an offer. She accepted. We fired her three months later.

Wow, there were just so many things I did wrong here.

• Big company experience rarely translates well to the startup world
• I wasn't ready to "share my legos" and so I micro-managed her work, giving overly detailed feedback on everything she turned in
• My feedback came couched in so many caveats, and I never said "This isn't how we talk to our target market, and here's why and what good looks like" or provided her with any kind of style guide
• We didn't really have a content strategy in place, we just wanted to "do more content" 
• By the time my manager realized how bad things were it was too late to salvage
I could go on. I felt absolutely awful after we let her go. We uprooted her from a great job and proceeded to just destroy her self-confidence for three months because I had no idea what I was doing. I've forgiven myself a bit for this only because, in retrospect, I realize how little support/training I was given as a new manager.

I've only very recently begun to see that that first data point on my people management skill is no longer representative, I'm actually pretty good, but it was a long slog getting here. I messed up terribly, and in a way that had a direct impact on someone's well-being.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: <@UJG12DM1V> I have failed to "share my legos" many times, and continue to find it difficult in some circumstances. Kudos to you for sharing and learning :slightly_smiling_face:
